Hi @susiwen8 sorry for the late reply.

> Because yAxis' extent only consider the data not the position of markpoint

I didn't understand this. Did you mean `value` type axis?

It will be great if you can give an example to explain it. I tried using `this.scale.contain(data)` and it works well on the example in the issue. I think it should make sense.

![Screen Shot 2019-11-06 at 13 28 47](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20318608/68270770-7a4bb680-0099-11ea-8ae2-1d88198ef919.png)
![Screen Shot 2019-11-06 at 13 28 57](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20318608/68270771-7a4bb680-0099-11ea-8274-56efeac21475.png)
![Screen Shot 2019-11-06 at 13 29 07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20318608/68270772-7ae44d00-0099-11ea-89cb-370f34be9357.png)
![Screen Shot 2019-11-06 at 13 29 12](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20318608/68270774-7ae44d00-0099-11ea-9314-9a5b43a13e1f.png)
@pissang Because the yAxis of markpoint for Aug and Dec are way higher than value, they aren't fit in Y axis if we use scale. Scale only consider data not markpoint.

Understand. I think it's another issue: If markPoint should be clipped if it exceed the axis. It should be a logic in mark point. Not in the underlying coordinate system.

But in this issue. Using `this.scale.contain(data)` would make more sense for the method `containData`.

I have found another bug, It should be 'æœ€å¤§å€¼' https://github.com/apache/incubator-echarts/blob/master/src/data/List.js#L1226

Eastern European Summer Time is a daylight saving time zone with which different browsers handle in different ways, e.g., the timestamp 1572469200000 in Firefox is equivalent to '2019-10-31 00:00', but in Chrome it is '2019-10-30 23:00'.
I'm not sure whether this is a bug. Hereby to let you know. @100pah

I think `_unfocusDelayTimer ` needs to be cleared when `graph` / `sankey` status is changed.

Like in the `render` and `focusNodeAdjacency`.

@devyumao Chrome and Firefox are the same in my computer for `new Date(1572469200000)`,
they are both `Wed Oct 30 2019 23:00:00 GMT+0200 (Eastern European Standard Time)`

@gajus 
By default, echarts uses local timezone to formate time labels.
But if we set timezone to Eastern European, there would be 
`Eastern European Summer Time` issue, as @devyumao said.

The boundary of `Eastern European Summer Time` and `Eastern European Standard Time` is:
```
new Date(1572137999999)
Sun Oct 27 2019 03:59:59 GMT+0300 (Eastern European Summer Time)
new Date(1572137999999 + 1)
Sun Oct 27 2019 03:00:00 GMT+0200 (Eastern European Standard Time)
```

In your case, the time axis is from Oct 1 to Oct 31, which crosses the boundary (about Oct 27),
so the time labels look weird.

So, the option [useUTC](http://echarts.apache.org/en/option.html#useUTC) is recommended in your case:
```js
option = {
    useUTC: true,
    xAxis: {...},
    yAxis: {...}
    series: {
        ...
    }
}
```
If you are using string-formatted time in data (for example, `"2019-10-01"`),
we do not need to convert the time to UTC, it's OK to keep the current time data.
The `useUTC` just make sure all of the string time formatted in consistent way.
You're welcome, and thanks for adding the themes!

Showing tooltip when hovering on legend is not supported, so this is not a bug.
What if we provide a new event called `legendhovered` similar to [legendselected](https://echarts.apache.org/en/api.html#events.legendselected) only that it triggers when the user hovers on the legend? If this meets your requirements, please open a new issue for feature request.

Perhaps the `var myChart = echarts.init(document.getElementById('bar'));` is called before ECharts `<script>` tag? This is a pure JS problem and ECharts won't give this error if `echarts` variable is there. Please have a carefully check.

So you want two axes on two sides, and they are the same?
You can set `yAxis` to be an array of y axes and max value should be set to make sure they are the same. Then, hide `splitLine` of the right axis.
